title: SCB list click is broken
body:
[Visit issue world](http://lively-web.org/issues/13-11-25_SCB_list_click_is_broken.html)

reported by robertkrahn:open a scb and browse to some method. now click into the second pane on the containing object (that is already selected).Expected behavior: the object/class is selectedCurrent behavior: nothing happens, the method is still selected

title: World-based Config
body:
While searching through the system for options to set Config settings, I only found the following places: defaultconfig.js, localconfig.js, user config (if user name is set in LivelyStorage) and URL parameters.

In (much) older versions we also had the option to set config settings for one page/world only.
Even though it was not used that often, I think it is worth having it again and I have three ideas on how it could be implemented:

1. Global config
A global option that contains a key (page) -> value (object with overridden options) object. Unfortunately this would not be "copied" when saving worlds to a different page.

2. JavaScript-Tag on page
This is the way it used to be implemented: A separate JavaScript-tag inside the HTML page that sets the initial Config object.

3. Linearized Object Graph Extension
An extension to the linearized object graph so it can contain "meta information" like page-/world-based config options.

Votes and comments are welcome! ;-)

title: Add simple hover effects to code browser and other list elements
body:
Give the user some visual feedback when hovering over list items (e.g. in the code browser) so that the current item is highlighted.
This is already implemented in the context menu of the world. Adding it to the other GUI elements would be more consistent and would feel more responsive.

title: Improve behaviour when editing scripts in the Object Editor
body:
- When creating a new script, "All Scripts" in the left pane is still highlighted. I would suggest to add a "New Script" item in the left pane even if the user hasn't saved anything. If he decides to discard the new script, the item would be removed from the pane.
- Change behaviour to “rename script” instead of “create new script” when saving a script with a different name. This would be more consistent with the behaviour of the code browser, and seems more intuitive to me.
- Mark unsaved scripts in the left pane. This could be done with a asterisk in the name (e.g. *Script) or by writing the name in italics. The red small square in the top right corner isn't the ideal place in my opinion. This would yield several advantages:
    - When creating a new script and immediately appending it to the left pane, the user would still understand that the script isn't saved anywhere.
    - Since each script-name can be marked as unsaved independently, one could think about making it possible to switch between two unsaved scripts (without being forced to save or discard the current state).
- Hide the "this.addScript(...)" wrapper in the scripts contents since it doesn't provide any value to the user.

title: Add a splitter/midResizer to the global search window "ToolTabPane"
body: The global search window “ToolTabPane” (opened per ctrl+shift+f) doesn’t allow to resize the top and bottom pane independently. A “midResizer” should be placed here like in the system browser.

title: Make the System Code Browser behave like the Finder from Mac OS X
body:
When navigating through folders in the System Code Browser, the Browser has got four top views from which only the first view is used.
For example, the OS X Finder handles this by showing the content to a clicked folder in the next (right) pane. If all four panes are occupied, a new pane would get inserted on the right and the view scrolls to the right (so that the left most pane isn't shown anymore).

This has the following advantages:
- the available screen real estate is used more effecient
- the user has a better overview about the folders he browsed through
- navigating multiple levels up gets as easy as clicking on the appropriate pane

A bonus feature would be to make navigating through the browser possible by using the keyboard-arrows.

title: Change standard keyboard shortcuts for jumping-per-word-basis on Windows
body:
Make ctrl+arrow-keys (on mac it is alt+arrow-keys which works) jump on a per-word-basis; ctrl+shift+arrow-keys should select whole words (this is the OS standard behaviour).
The preferences say that Control-Left is bound to “moveBackwardToMatching”. When changing moveBackwardToMatching (without creating a new shortcut), the standard behaviour of the OS should work automatically.

This would partly be resolved by #195

title: make keyboard shortcuts in preferences-pane editable
Improve "Get halo on..."-menu
body:
Opening the menu could be simplified by a simple ctrl+rightclick on the desired morph. Then the normla "get halo on"-menu would be opened to display a list of all underlying morphs.

Furthermore, one could highlight the corresponding morph when hovering through the "get halo on"-menu.

title: No difference between “Browse Senders”, “Browse Implementors” and normal Search ?
body: There doesn’t seem to be difference between “Browse Senders”, “Browse Implementors” and normal Search (with ctrl+shift+f) for any input.

body:
The MagnifierButton behaves very strange when hovering over morphs. Morphs aren't properly uncolored.
Closing the ObjectEditor doesn't leave the "Magnifier-Mode".
Moving Morphs which are highlighted leads to the following picture:

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2486553/1551025/295cdf32-4e0d-11e3-888c-3680119cebcf.png)

title: Right-Click on "World -> Documentation -> More” opens <server>/documentation/ which yields a “file not found”-error
body: only applies for local instances

title: Holding CTRL and dragging the mouse opens halos
body:
When holding CTRL and dragging the mouse (to create another text selection in the code editor), the mouse-up-event will show the halos of the underlying morphs.
The halos should only appear if the mouse wasn’t moved between Down- and Up-event.

title: Mouse-Up-Event isn't recognized if the mouse isn't released on the same morph

This occurs especially often when I try to select code in a CodeEditor starting from the bottom right to the top left (where the top left is a few pixels outside the code editor)
![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/2486553/1550872/35fbdbaa-4e0b-11e3-9959-bc249d81ee16.png)

This issue seems to be present only under Windows.

title: cannot scroll in find window
body:
[Visit issue world](http://lively-web.org/issues/13-10-15_cannot_scroll_list_in_find_window.html)

Search for e.g. "delay" using cmd-shift-f. Without activating the Find window, scrolling the list of hits works fine using the mouse's scrool wheel. However, after activating the window, the list does not scroll anymore. Only after deactivating it again, it works.

body:
[Visit issue world](http://lively-web.org/issues/13-10-09_changing_selection_in_SCB_with_unsaved_changes_results_in_inconsistent_state.html)

if you change the current selection (in any of the list panes) in the SCB while having unsaved changes in the code pane, then chose to not discard the changes (click cancel), the SCB is in an inconsistent state, since the selection does changes (and it shows changed), but it does not correspond anymore with the other panes, which were not updated correspondingly

title: memory leak -- traits applied to objects
body:
[Visit issue world](http://lively-web.org/issues/13-10-08_memory_leak.html)

as reported by @fmateoc 

We have a memory leak with traits when applied to objects. The trait's extendedObjectsAndOptions holds the objects long after they are (should be) gone. I noticed this with the DragMoveTrait

title: if a list items are set to empty after they were non-empty and the list had a scrollbar, the list does not lose the scrollbar
Running a server-log view crashes Lively tab
body:
Opening a server log view (world menu -> Tools -> Subserver Viewer -> "open log" button) allows you to monitor all requests being handled by the Lively server.

However, at least when running on Chrome (today on version 29.0.1547.76), after having the log open for a while the whole Lively tab crashes ("Aw, snap!").

It's not clear what determines how long it takes for the crash to happen: maybe elapsed time, maybe number of requests displayed.  Today, with the server handling a few requests per second from a LivelyR client, the page would crash reliably (!) within about 20 minutes.

Even with Chrome crash reporting enabled, these crashes are somehow not recorded.

title: Cmd-c doesn't work to do copy in Safari
body:
Cmd-c doesn't work all the time to do copy in Safari. copy via menu works.

reported by @Daningalls

title: Bug alert boxes are too small to show the bug error message
body:
All I see is a red box, with some writing that indicates that this is an error alert -- in order to read the problem, I need to throw a halo around the alert box, and then open an inspector and go through the fields (which involves opening up subfields) to see what the problem was.

Could one workaround be to generate a Javascript alert box?

title: Global.classes(true) includes duplicates
body: `Global.classes(true)` should return classes of all namespaces but includes some classes more than once. This is because Module>>gather invokes the `classes` method recursively and for nested modules such as `lively.bindings.Core` classes are added for each subnamespace.

title: Global eval in workspace not working
body:
With the changes introduced in d5a34c1 a statement like

```js
x = 3;
```

when evaluated in a workspace throws an error if `x` is not defined.

title: Window: Much more responsive without CSS shadows
SCB: LocationPane: issues / ideas for improvement
body:
text partially copied from a mail: 

In the file path, when the user has a specific file selected, the file name itself could be included. The user wants to copy this out and get a more-or-less complete path.
        
While it is nice to take off the path before /core/, it is unnerving to see nothing in that space when you are looking at /core/. One might prefer to see the entire path all the time.  Naive user don't know what is going on.  Maybe a menu item with 'copy full url' to let them see the real complete path.

The switch between [Codebase] and [local] is hidden.  New users will never know to right click to find that hidden switch!  How about a small button the brings up a menu?

The name 'local' should be changed to something more appropriate such as 'Your Directory' ... 
Note:
If the world is on a server, [local] lets you see:
lively-kernel.org/core/users/YourName/
If you are running locally, [local] lets you see:
localhost:9001/users/YourName/


Perhaps that same menu could include an item: [ copy do-it ].  This would copy the text (for example) '$world.browseCode("lively.morphic.World", "createStatusMessage", "lively.morphic.MorphAddons");'.   The purpose is to let a user paste this text into email or skype.  The user needs to tell another person where to find a specific piece of code.

In summary, an additional button specific for the LocationPane could bring up this menu:
[Go to Codebase]
[Go to Your Directory]
[Copy full URL]
[Copy path do-it]

title: SCB: Wrong selections after activating Sort
body: When a browser's panes have selections and you use the *Sort* command from the browser's menu, the lists all continue to show selections at the previously selected indexes, which then often no longer show the same items.

title: SCB: Not possible to add and remove protocols via context menu
body:
Currently, it's only possible to change the protocols of a class when you select a module or a class and, then, change whole definitions at once. It's not possible to add or remove context menus using the context menu of the third pane, which shows protocols for classes. 
If deleting a protocol also should delete all methods in that protocol, this action should probably prompt for confirmation before doing so...

Also, when you select a protocol in the third pane, you can't bring up the context menu.

title: SCB: Protocol pane can't be saved
body:
Currently, it's possible to change the code that you see for a protocol that you previously selected from the third pane of the SCB, but you can't save these changes.

Would be great and consistent if it were possible to save changes done in that pane as well. 
Or, alternatively, to prevent working on whole protocols by not showing the code editor with just a protocol. Instead selecting a protocol could just update the method list, just like the SCB's inspiration in Squeak.

title: SCB: Broken context menu operations
body:
In the context menu that you get when you right click the second pane–which shows classes, extensions, and layers–there's the option to *view hierarchy*, but clicking it results in an error.

In the context menu of the fourth pane that shows methods, the *senders* and *implementors* items seem broken.

Might be okay to at least remove the list items for these broken commands for the time being.

title: SCB: The selection is missing in copied and reloaded browsers
body:
When you copy a browser, the new browser doesn't show the content of the original browser. 
When a world is saved with some system code browsers, these browsers are there when you reload the world, but empty.

The problem is that the *getSelection* / *setSelection* / *selectNode* methods don't work anymore. I think they (at least) assume lists build out of morphs and not the currently used HTML list elements...

title: SCB: Missing a comma after a method results in a syntax error
body:
It's possible to miss the comma after a method in SCB. That comma is necessary when another method follows in that protocol (or just the class for uncategorized methods) and such a missing comma is a syntax error.

It's possible to manually remove that comma.
And I think the comma is also not added automatically when a method is added at the end of a protocol or the end of the class...but then you might add another method...

Would be nice if the parser would ensure these commas. And even nicer if they wouldn't be visible in the SCB's method-view at all as that would further abstract from the file nature of our code base.

title: Event cleanup
body:
This is a larger code cleanup and gets rid of lively.EventExperiments.

With evt.getTargetMorph() we get a fast and central mechanism to lookup morphs that are event targets. This allows to put "meta event handling" (halos, "that", drag dispatch, etc.) in the mouse down/up/move handlers of the World which considerably frees the default mouse(down/up)entry methods of Morph.

Caveat, though: This mechanism uses the DOM (which makes it fast) and does not consider specific Morphic handling. E.g. when "grabbing" a morph and trying to find a drop target for it this mechanism can not be used because the grabbed morph will "block" other morphs. For this we still need #morphsContainingPoint.

title: WIP: Model sync
body:
starting with an interface for syncing changes between objects stored in a local or remote data store. The interface for now includes:

## ObjectHandle

### read
- `#get`
- `#subscribe`

### write
- `#set`
- `#commit` (set ensuring no overwrites)

##  Local Store
- currently synchronous object store
- outlines an interface required by any store

Thinks I'm working on:
- remote store
- (sub)handle access
- reading tree changes
- synchronization for collections

title: Show graceful error when PartsBin not found
body: See https://github.com/LivelyKernel/LivelyKernel/issues/119 for the current state.

title: Bugfix for removeAfterUpdate
body:
The ``removeAfterUpdate`` property of a connection is used to make a connection fire only once. The problem is that the current implementation remove the attribute connection for that source/target combination regardless of whether this connection was changed or re-connected during the update.

One solution would be to introduce a new property called ``removeBeforeUpdate`` but this patch implements a simpler approach that uses a flag to check whether a connection needs to be removed or not.

title: WIP: Fixing text padding
WIP: Lively store
body:
Serialization interface that provides very simple access (key/value read and writes) to different backends. Supposed to be used for per-app persistence. Possibly also an option for storing worlds and for a future wiki / PartsBin.

Supported backends right now:

- JS object
- files
- CouchDB (needs [couchdb subserver](https://github.com/LivelyKernel/subserver-couchdb.git))

title: Toggle buttons and normal Buttons look the same
body: .. on Windows and Unix machines, browser independent. It works fine in a Chrome on Mac.

title: Style editor is unfriendly
body:
From Dan:

In the style editor, if the object in view has not been named, the top pane shows ‘undefined’.  This is not friendly to the non-expert user:  what is undefined; should she try to fix it, etc??  Better would be to present the assigned name, as is done in the halo.

title: Update 2.1.4 changelog
body:
Needs some filtering. So far:

Features:
* lk install (yet to fix)

Minor features:
* added assertRaises to TestCase
* added test spies
* adding date format lib to standard extensions
* extending #setClipMode: Paramter can either be a string or an object. String: "visible", "hidden", "auto", "scroll" Object: should have x and/or y field with a string og the choices above.
* lively.morphic.createN as a way to optimize the creation of multiple similar morphs. using it for the grid layout
* better support for serialization debuging: serializer.findIdReferencePathFromToId now prints a proper JS accessor path
* upload images with dragn-dop + alt pressed
* native context menu with ctrl + alt + click
* morph diffing...?
* text shadows
* Text interface extensions...?
    * text morph now supports setFontWeight, setFontStyle, setTextDecoration as getters/setters & in applyStyle
    * insert methods...?
* lively.Config improvements, per-user config support, config-url override
    * reading pre-bootstrap config
    * usage tracking
* lively.whenLoaded callback
* support for creating string tables
* password input morph
* SystemConsole for displaying log and error messages in Lively
* Improved Inspector
* new morph: lively.morphic.Tree

Fixes:
* optimize grid layout
* correct mouse pos when world is offseted
* restore text selection on focus
* traits applied to objects get serialized
* fix pasting of richt text
* DOM selection fixes or FF and Chrome
* tabindex fix
* suppress scrollbar click
* PUT and other methods were sometimes "cached" in Chrome

Optimizations
* array method optimizations

title: How to get specific "components" reusable outside of LK
body:
So the use case is that we have a awesome framework with lots of cool features like a class system, data bindings, stuff and we want  to make those things reusable without having to pull in the whole Lively package (even if it's just the core, the core is at least currently too big). Also our module system more or less is a problem for that since it would be required if you want to reuse, say, the class system. Plus, you would have to use XHR it's load mechanism which might not be usable in all environments (say, node). Of course we could adapt our modules to different environments (node.js require e.g.) but this is probably another project.

So, what JS people usually do is to provide compiled scripts that could just be included (remotely like including jquery from google or via script download & add it locally to your page).

Idea: Let's have a component interface based on our combinedModules. A request to http://lively-kernel.org/modules/lk-classes.js could for example package the necessary code that is needed just for the class system (we get the requirements via our module definitions) together and make it embedable via `<script src="http://lively-kernel.org/modules/lk-classes.js" /> and downloadable.

We could also automatically remove all `module(...)` expressions to just deliver the plain code. So there is no need for "simulating" modules like we do it for the combinedModules load process in pur bootstrap (we need that there because there could be modules that are required in the code but are not part of the combinedModules).


@fbornhofen @lauritzthamsen @JensLincke please comment. Thx :-)

title: Red/broken test cases excluded from default test runs
body:
The default test run for this repository does not run all available test modules as several are red (partly because they rely on the Lively Wiki infrastructure / the Webwerkstatt deployment) or don't return at all. We should remove Wiki-dependent / Webwerkstatt tests from this repository and the [default test run](https://github.com/rksm/LivelyKernel/blob/master/testing/run_tests.js) should incorporate all test modules.

__Test runs fail / red__

cop.tests.LayerInliningTests
cop.tests.TracingTests

lively.tests.ScriptingTests
lively.tests.BootstrapTests
lively.tests.CoreTest
lively.tests.NetworkTest

__Tests don't run through / test timeout__

lively.tests.LKWikiTests

title: [tests] Code coverage
body: We want Lively's Core to be stable and, therefore, run our tests continuously. Code coverage information would help to identify  not well tested modules and, therefore, would help to get more of the Core into a test harness.

title: [WW integration] view and add github issues from Lively
body: Use the Markdown morph to interface github issues in Lively. Load title, label, and issue description from github, while Lively worlds provide an environment for the reproduction of defects or general examples.

title: [Class system] Static / class-side methods through subclass and addMethods
body:
We add non-instance methods to the Object itself through _Object.extend()_, which does not incorporate method categories. Further, it's not clearly shown as part of the class definition in source files and the SCB. 

Would be in favor of having distinguished class-side methods similar to our instance-side methods through _ addClassMethods()_ and in _subclass()_ definitions. With method categories.

title: [text] lively.morphic.tests.TextMorphTests.test05bSetSelectionRangeRightToLeft
Too many extensions to Array and Enumerable isn't used elsewhere
body:
Interface of array feels quite big, with a couple of very similar functions. We even have some aliases...
If you count the function definitions in lively.lang.Array you'll get ridiculously close to 50...

Also, the _Enumerable_ object is created in lively.lang.Array and immediately mixed into the _Array.prototype_. I think that it's not used elsewhere - so we might skip this step as well in an effort to get a smaller Array interface...

title: [tests] Tests should fail if test modules cannot be loaded (syntax errors, etc)
body: When there are syntax errors in modules, CLI test runner fails with a timeout. It should be able to report syntax errors.

title: [DISCUSSION] Github Lively integration
body:
@fbornhofen @lauritzthamsen 

So I have been thinking quite a lot about how to get our little experiment well integrated into the Lively workflow.

For now just so much that I'm *very* excited about the github API, e.g. [issues](http://developer.github.com/v3/issues/) and [repos](http://developer.github.com/v3/repos/downloads/).

How about creating a little entry in the world menu that says "report a bug" that will then automatically create a github issue? Maybe also when a red error message pops up. We can have this links/button in alerts that could automatically be used for the description...!

With trac this is a real pain but this seems to be much nicer... anyone volunteering?
